Peter, you make a good point that there is a challenge in interpreting
arbi=
trary CPPN patterns as distinct physical objects.  I think ideas
like yours=
 are indeed important to explore to potentially address the
issue, and I fo=
und your shape-evolving novelty search program along
those lines very inter=
esting.  Since you have most experience with the
idea, I am curious, do you=
 get the sense after playing with it a lot
that the patterns that come out =
are indeed sufficiently diverse and
regular to potentially represent animal=
 morphologies?  Or does there
seem to be anything lacking from the output o=
f such systems?

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <peta=
r_chervenski@...>
wrote:
>
> I'd like to point out that CPPNs can be combin=
ed effectively with 
> cellular growth models. Because the cells need the a=
nswer to the 
> question "Who am I?", the CPPN can provide that info withou=
t any 
> interaction between cells. It can also provide instructions about,=
 for 
> example "Should I divide or not? Should I change my type?". 
> Whil=
e it seems like an overkill, because CPPNs already abstract this 
> away wi=
thout having to introduce time for development, the patterns 
> generated a=
re hard to interpret as distinct physical objects. 
> Especially in cases o=
f repeating patterns. But objects generated with 
> cellular growth instruc=
ted by CPPNs produce only a single object, all 
> with its distinct parts a=
nd regularities. And not ripped apart with 
> artifacts as it would be afte=
r converting it from a CPPN snapshot 
> image. One might say that such obje=
cts can still be infinte in size, 
> but it is easy to put a limitation on =
the number of cells or cell 
> divisions. It is also possible to make the l=
imit dynamic, more complex 
> CPPNs producing phenotypes with more cells.
>=
 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> w=
rote:
> >
> > Alexandre, thank you for bringing up reaction-diffusion syste=
ms.  
> You
> > make a good point- my statement was too broad, in part beca=
use
> > "cellular growth model" is a fairly ambiguous term that can
> > pot=
entially refer to many types of systems.  
> > 
> > Just to clarify my stat=
ement, I was responding the line of 
> discussion
> > with Peter about enco=
dings that actually create distinct bodily 
> shapes
> > that are self-cont=
ained and have clear structural boundaries (which
> > reaction-diffusion sy=
stems tend not to produce; rather they produce
> > wallpaper-like patterns)=
.  Often when growth-based models are used 
> to
> > define actual bodies w=
ith distinct borders, they are studied in the
> > context of blobs with a p=
articular focus on how the blob knows when 
> to
> > stop growing so that a=
 border shape can be created.  That kind of
> > systems goes along with the=
 "skin" issue that we were discussing.
> > 
> > Nevertheless, the field is =
quite broad and there are many possible
> > interesting examples of such sy=
stems.  If I could revisit my
> > statement, I would reword it such as to a=
void implying any sweeping
> > generalization.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > 
> > -=

> >=
 > Hello

wth model
> > produce anything more than a blob or an amorphous shape witho=
ut 
> clear
> > parts."
> > >

tems as a cellular growth
> > model, then you might consider the following =
publications :
> > > "Interactive Evolution of Dynamical Systems, Karl Sims=
"
> > > "Advanced Reaction-Diffusion Models for Texture Synthesis, Allen 
>=
 R.
> > Sanderson et al."

verage blob and features very
